msgSnippet: I assume that you re using the junit.swingui.TestRunner class.  A first question to ask is, if you re only doing 50 tests, why is JUnit up and running for

From: "Mason, Kim" <kimm@...>

I assume that you're using the junit.swingui.TestRunner class.  A first
question to ask is, if you're only doing 50 tests, why is JUnit up and
running for hours at a time?  You must be testing some pretty
computation/communication intensive code.

Try running the same tests using junit.textui.TestRunner.  If it still goes
bung, I'd think that it's probably your code that's taking up the space.
Try increasing the heap size available to the JVM (the switch is
-mx<amountofram>m .

Kim.

-----Original Message-----
From: Hugo Garcia [mailto:elhugonyc@...]
Sent: Friday, 23 March 2001 8:42 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] OutOfMemoryError


make your stack bigger when you call java????

-H


--- Frank Enos <fenos@...> wrote:
> Hi all.
> 
> I'm wondering if anyone might have a strong opinion about the likely cause

> of a java.lang.OutOfMemoryError in the awt version of the UI.
> 
> It's happened a few times after I've had JUnit up and running for hours at

> a time.
> 
> I'm wondering if anyone's experience might point toward memory leaks in
the 
> code being tested, (I know, "this is Java...") leaks in the tests, 
> over-taxed JUnit (not that many tests, though, about 50), or something
else.
> 
> Thanks,
> Frank
> 
> Frank Enos
> Merkley Newman Harty
